canonical_explanation.text: Hydrogen occupies a unique position in the periodic table due to its electronic configuration (1s¹) resembling both alkali metals (ns¹) and halogens (one electron short of noble gas). It exists as three isotopes: protium (¹H), deuterium (²H or D), and tritium (³H or T). Dihydrogen (H₂) is prepared industrially and in the laboratory through various methods and is used as a fuel and reducing agent. Hydrides are classified as ionic (formed with electropositive metals), covalent (with nonmetals), and interstitial (with transition metals). Water has unique properties due to extensive hydrogen bonding, existing in hard and soft forms. Heavy water (D₂O) has higher boiling point and density than ordinary water. Hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) is a powerful oxidizing agent with a non-planar open-book structure.
rules: Hydrogen has three isotopes: protium (mass 1), deuterium (mass 2), and tritium (mass 3, radioactive).
Hydrides are ionic (NaH, CaH₂), covalent (H₂O, NH₃, CH₄), or interstitial (TiH, PdH).
Water has anomalous properties: high boiling point, high specific heat, maximum density at 4°C, all due to hydrogen bonding.
H₂O₂ acts as both an oxidizing and reducing agent; its structure is non-planar with an O-O bond.

questions.question_text: The isotope of hydrogen that is radioactive is:

options.text: All isotopes of hydrogen are stable

questions.explanation_correct: Tritium (³H) is the radioactive isotope of hydrogen. It has one proton and two neutrons in the nucleus, making it unstable and prone to radioactive decay.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Protium (¹H) and deuterium (²H) are both stable isotopes of hydrogen. Tritium (³H) is the radioactive isotope, as it has an extra neutron in the nucleus, making it unstable and prone to radioactive decay.

questions.question_text: Hydrogen resembles alkali metals because:

options.text: It has one electron in its outermost shell
It is a good conductor of electricity
It has a high ionization energy

questions.explanation_correct: Hydrogen resembles alkali metals because it has one electron in its outermost shell, just like the alkali metals (such as sodium and potassium). This electronic configuration gives hydrogen similar chemical properties to the alkali metals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hydrogen does not form diatomic molecules like oxygen (O₂) or nitrogen (N₂). Hydrogen normally exists as a diatomic molecule (H₂). Hydrogen is also not a good conductor of electricity, and it has a high ionization energy, unlike the alkali metals which have low ionization energies. So the correct answer is that hydrogen resembles alkali metals because it has one electron in its outermost shell.

questions.question_text: Hydrogen can be prepared in the laboratory by the reaction of zinc with:
questions.explanation_correct: Hydrogen can be prepared in the laboratory by the reaction of zinc with dilute hydrochloric acid (HCl). This is because zinc is an electropositive metal that reacts with the hydrogen ions (H+) in the dilute acid to produce dihydrogen (H2) gas.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because concentrated sulfuric acid (H2SO4) and concentrated nitric acid (HNO3) are too strong and will not selectively produce hydrogen gas. Concentrated sodium hydroxide (NaOH) is a base, not an acid, and will not react with zinc to produce hydrogen.

questions.question_text: Hydrogen resembles halogens because it:

options.text: Needs one electron to complete its shell and forms H⁻ ion
Exists only as a monoatomic gas

questions.explanation_correct: Hydrogen resembles halogens because it needs one electron to complete its electron shell and form the H⁻ ion, similar to how halogens like chlorine need one electron to form the Cl⁻ ion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hydrogen does not form ionic hydrides with metals like alkali metals do. Instead, it forms covalent hydrides with nonmetals. Hydrogen is also not a strong oxidizing agent, and it can exist in diatomic form as H₂ gas, not just as a monoatomic gas.

questions.question_text: The bond angle in water molecule is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: The bond angle in the water molecule is approximately 104.5°. This is because the oxygen atom in water has two bonding pairs of electrons and two lone pairs of electrons, which results in a tetrahedral arrangement around the oxygen atom. This tetrahedral arrangement leads to the observed bond angle of approximately 104.5°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct bond angle in the water molecule is approximately 104.5°, not 90°, 109.5°, or 120°. The 104.5° bond angle is due to the tetrahedral arrangement of the two bonding pairs and two lone pairs of electrons around the central oxygen atom. The 90° option is incorrect because it does not match the actual bond angle, while 109.5° and 120° are the bond angles of other molecular geometries, such as those of methane (CH4) and benzene (C6H6), respectively, which do not apply to the water molecule.

questions.question_text: Heavy water (D₂O) is used as a:
questions.explanation_correct: Heavy water (D₂O) is used as a moderator in nuclear reactors because its higher density and boiling point compared to regular water (H₂O) make it more effective at slowing down neutrons without absorbing them, which is crucial for the nuclear fission process.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Heavy water cannot be used as a fuel in nuclear reactors, as it is not radioactive like uranium or plutonium. It also cannot be used as a coolant in refrigerators, as its properties are not suitable for that purpose. While heavy water can be used as a solvent for organic synthesis, it has many other important applications in nuclear technology as a moderator.

questions.question_text: The structure of hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) is:
questions.explanation_correct: The structure of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is non-planar with an open-book configuration. This is because the oxygen-oxygen bond creates an angle between the two O-H bonds, resulting in a bent, non-planar molecular structure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The structure of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is not linear, planar, or tetrahedral. It has a non-planar, open-book configuration due to the angle created by the oxygen-oxygen bond. This bent structure is the most stable and energetically favourable arrangement for the hydrogen peroxide molecule.

questions.question_text: H₂O₂ acts as an oxidizing agent when it reacts with:
questions.explanation_correct: Hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) is a powerful oxidizing agent, meaning it can easily transfer oxygen to other substances. When it reacts with lead(II) sulfide (PbS), it oxidizes the sulfur to sulfate (SO₄²⁻), converting PbS to lead(II) sulfate (PbSO₄).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) is not the correct oxidizing agent for the other options. With acidified potassium permanganate (KMnO₄), it acts as a reducing agent. With ozone (O₃), it does not undergo any reaction. And with chlorine (Cl₂), it would form chloride ions (Cl⁻) and perchloric acid (HClO₄), not acting as an oxidizing agent in this case.

questions.question_text: NaH is an example of a:
questions.explanation_correct: NaH is an example of an ionic hydride because it is formed between the highly electropositive metal sodium (Na) and the highly electronegative hydrogen (H). Ionic hydrides are compounds where hydrogen acts as a negatively charged hydride ion (H-) and forms a salt-like structure with the positively charged metal cation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not correct because: A) Covalent hydrides are formed between hydrogen and non-metals, C) Interstitial hydrides are formed by inserting hydrogen atoms into the crystal lattice of transition metals, and D) Metallic hydrides are formed by dissolving hydrogen in the lattice of certain metals. NaH is an ionic hydride, not any of these other types.

questions.question_text: Interstitial hydrides are formed by:
questions.explanation_correct: Interstitial hydrides are formed by d-block and f-block elements, as these metals have empty spaces or 'interstices' in their crystal structures where hydrogen atoms can be accommodated.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Interstitial hydrides are not formed by alkali metals, halogens, or noble gases. Alkali metals form ionic hydrides, halogens form covalent hydrides, and noble gases do not form any hydrides. Only the d-block and f-block elements, which have partially filled d and f orbitals, can form interstitial hydrides by incorporating hydrogen atoms into the empty spaces within their crystal structures.

questions.question_text: Water has an anomalously high boiling point compared to H₂S because of:

options.text: Van der Waals forces in water are stronger

questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) Extensive hydrogen bonding in water. Water molecules can form hydrogen bonds with each other, resulting in a higher boiling point compared to other similar molecules like H2S that do not have extensive hydrogen bonding.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answers are not correct because: A) The molecular mass of water (18 g/mol) is not higher than that of H2S (34 g/mol), so this does not explain the higher boiling point. C) The O-H bond in water is a covalent bond, not an ionic bond. D) Van der Waals forces in water are not stronger than the hydrogen bonding, which is the primary reason for the high boiling point.

questions.question_text: The mass ratio of protium to deuterium is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: The mass ratio of protium (¹H) to deuterium (²H or D) is approximately 1:2. This is because deuterium has double the mass of protium due to the additional neutron in its nucleus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A (1:1) is incorrect because protium and deuterium have significantly different masses. Option C (1:3) and D (2:3) are also incorrect as the mass ratio is not 1:3 or 2:3. The correct answer is option B (1:2) because the mass of deuterium is twice that of protium.

questions.question_text: The boiling point of D₂O compared to H₂O is:
questions.explanation_correct: The boiling point of D₂O (heavy water) is higher than that of H₂O (normal water) because deuterium (²H) is heavier than protium (¹H), leading to stronger hydrogen bonding and higher intermolecular attractions. This increases the boiling point of heavy water compared to regular water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The boiling point of heavy water (D₂O) is higher than that of normal water (H₂O) because the heavier deuterium atoms have stronger intermolecular attractions, resulting in a higher boiling point. Option A is incorrect because the boiling point of heavy water is 101.4°C, not lower. Option B is incorrect because the boiling points are not the same. Option D is incorrect because the boiling point is not much higher, just 1.4°C higher than regular water.

questions.question_text: H₂O is an example of a ___ hydride:
questions.explanation_correct: H₂O is a covalent hydride because hydrogen forms a covalent bond with the nonmetal oxygen to form water, which is a neutral compound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: H₂O is not an ionic hydride because it does not involve a reaction between hydrogen and an electropositive metal. It is also not an interstitial hydride, which is formed when hydrogen occupies the spaces between the atoms of a transition metal. H₂O is a covalent hydride, where hydrogen forms a covalent bond with the nonmetal oxygen.

questions.question_text: Temporary hardness of water is caused by the presence of:
questions.explanation_correct: Temporary hardness of water is caused by the presence of bicarbonates of calcium and magnesium. These bicarbonates can be easily removed by boiling the water, which causes them to decompose and form insoluble carbonates, reducing the hardness of the water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options do not cause temporary hardness of water. Chlorides and sulfates of calcium and magnesium, as well as sodium chloride, contribute to the permanent hardness of water, which cannot be removed by boiling. Only bicarbonates of calcium and magnesium can cause temporary hardness that can be eliminated by boiling the water.

questions.question_text: Dihydrogen is a:
questions.explanation_correct: Dihydrogen (H2) is a diatomic nonpolar molecule because it has two hydrogen atoms that share a pair of electrons equally, resulting in a symmetrical structure with no net dipole moment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dihydrogen is not a monoatomic gas since it has two hydrogen atoms bonded together. It is also not a triatomic molecule, which would have three atoms. The correct answer is that dihydrogen is a diatomic nonpolar molecule, as the two hydrogen atoms share a pair of electrons equally, giving the molecule a symmetrical and nonpolar structure.

questions.question_text: H₂O₂ acts as a reducing agent when it reacts with:
questions.explanation_correct: H₂O₂ acts as a reducing agent when it reacts with acidified potassium permanganate (KMnO₄) because it can donate electrons to the permanganate ion, reducing it from the +7 oxidation state to the +2 state of manganese ions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: H₂O₂ does not act as a reducing agent when reacting with ferrous sulfate, lead sulfide, or potassium iodide. Instead, it acts as an oxidizing agent in these reactions, accepting electrons and getting reduced itself to form water. The correct answer is option C, where H₂O₂ reduces the permanganate ion in acidic conditions.

questions.question_text: Ionic hydrides on electrolysis liberate hydrogen at the:
questions.explanation_correct: Ionic hydrides, such as LiH and NaH, are formed by the reaction of electropositive metals with hydrogen. During electrolysis, the positively charged metal cation will be reduced at the cathode, while the hydride ion (H-) will be oxidized at the anode to liberate hydrogen gas.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ionic hydrides cannot liberate hydrogen at the cathode during electrolysis. This is because the hydride ion (H-) is oxidized at the anode to produce hydrogen gas, not reduced at the cathode. The positively charged metal cation is the one that gets reduced at the cathode during the electrolysis of ionic hydrides.

questions.question_text: The reaction used for industrial preparation of dihydrogen by steam reforming is:

options.text: CH₄ + H₂O → CO + 3H₂ (at high temp with Ni catalyst)

questions.explanation_correct: The reaction used for industrial preparation of dihydrogen by steam reforming is B) CH₄ + H₂O → CO + 3H₂ (at high temp with Ni catalyst). This is because the steam reforming process involves the reaction of methane (natural gas) with water (steam) at high temperatures, in the presence of a nickel catalyst, to produce carbon monoxide and hydrogen gas.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not the correct reactions for the industrial preparation of dihydrogen by steam reforming. Option A is the reaction of zinc with hydrochloric acid, Option C is the reaction of sodium with water, and Option D is the electrolysis of water, none of which are the steam reforming process used industrially to produce hydrogen gas.

questions.question_text: Permanent hardness of water can be removed by:
questions.explanation_correct: Permanent hardness of water is caused by the presence of dissolved salts of calcium and magnesium, such as CaCl₂ and MgCl₂. Treatment with washing soda (Na₂CO₃) can remove this hardness by precipitating out the calcium and magnesium ions as insoluble carbonates.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Boiling water cannot remove permanent hardness, as the dissolved salts remain in the water even after boiling. Adding more CaCl₂ would increase the hardness of the water, not remove it. Filtration alone does not remove the dissolved salts responsible for permanent hardness.

questions.question_text: Which of the following hydrides is electron-deficient?
questions.explanation_correct: The hydride B₂H₆ is electron-deficient, meaning it has fewer electrons than needed for a stable structure. This is because boron (B) has only 3 valence electrons, and in B₂H₆ each boron is bonded to only 3 hydrogen atoms, resulting in an incomplete octet configuration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is C) B₂H₆. The other options are not electron-deficient hydrides. NH₃ (ammonia) and CH₄ (methane) have a complete octet configuration, while H₂O (water) has a bent molecular structure with a complete octet. Therefore, B₂H₆ is the only hydride in the given options that is electron-deficient.

questions.question_text: The oxidation state of hydrogen in most of its compounds is:
questions.explanation_correct: The oxidation state of hydrogen in most of its compounds is +1. This is because hydrogen has one electron in its outermost shell, and when it forms compounds, it typically loses this electron to form a positive charge of +1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is C, +1. Hydrogen can have an oxidation state of -1 when it forms compounds with highly electropositive elements like alkali metals, forming ionic hydrides. However, in most of its compounds, hydrogen has an oxidation state of +1, as it typically loses its one valence electron to form a positive charge. The oxidation states of +2 or 0 are less common for hydrogen.

questions.question_text: The volume strength of a '10 volume' H₂O₂ solution means:

options.text: 10 mL of H₂O₂ is dissolved in water
1 mL of H₂O₂ solution gives 10 mL of O₂ at STP

questions.explanation_correct: The volume strength of a '10 volume' H₂O₂ solution means that 1 mL of the solution can release 10 mL of oxygen gas at standard temperature and pressure (STP) when decomposed. This is because the concentration of the H₂O₂ solution is 10 times higher than the standard concentration of 3% H₂O₂.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because: A) This option describes the volume of H₂O₂ used to prepare the solution, not the volume strength. C) The concentration of a '10 volume' H₂O₂ solution is not 10 M. D) The concentration is not described in terms of mass per volume, but rather the volume of oxygen gas that can be produced.

questions.question_text: The thermal stability of hydrides of Group 16 decreases in the order:
questions.explanation_correct: The thermal stability of hydrides decreases as the size of the atom increases. This is because the heavier elements have weaker bonds, making the hydrides less stable. Therefore, the correct order is H₂O > H₂S > H₂Se > H₂Te.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because the thermal stability of hydrides actually decreases as the size of the atom increases. This is because the heavier elements have weaker bonds, making the hydrides less stable. Therefore, the correct order is H₂O > H₂S > H₂Se > H₂Te.

questions.question_text: Water achieves maximum density at:
questions.explanation_correct: Water achieves maximum density at 4°C because below this temperature, the hydrogen bonding between water molecules causes the liquid to expand and become less dense, while above 4°C, the thermal energy overcomes the hydrogen bonding and the density decreases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because water does not achieve maximum density at 0°C (it is the freezing point), 25°C (which is room temperature), or 100°C (which is the boiling point). The unique property of water is that it reaches its maximum density at 4°C, a few degrees above its freezing point.

questions.question_text: Which of the following reactions produces the purest form of hydrogen?
questions.explanation_correct: The electrolysis of acidified water produces the purest form of hydrogen gas as it separates hydrogen gas from the water molecules, leaving no impurities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While the other reactions (Zn + dil. H2SO4, reaction of Na with water, steam on hot coke) can also produce hydrogen gas, they result in the formation of impurities like metal ions or other byproducts. The electrolysis of acidified water is the cleanest method to obtain pure hydrogen gas.

questions.question_text: The hydride ion (H⁻) is formed when hydrogen reacts with:
questions.explanation_correct: The hydride ion (H⁻) is formed when hydrogen reacts with a highly electropositive metal like sodium. This is because hydrogen has a low electronegativity and can easily lose its single electron to form a negatively charged ion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The hydride ion (H⁻) is not formed when hydrogen reacts with chlorine, oxygen, or nitrogen. Chlorine is a halogen and will form a covalent bond with hydrogen to make hydrogen chloride (HCl). Oxygen and nitrogen are nonmetals, and they will also form covalent bonds with hydrogen, resulting in water (H₂O) and ammonia (NH₃) respectively, not the hydride ion.

questions.question_text: H₂O₂ is stored in wax-lined glass or plastic vessels in the dark because:

options.text: Light and rough surfaces catalyze its decomposition

questions.explanation_correct: Hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) is stored in wax-lined glass or plastic vessels in the dark because light and rough surfaces can catalyze its decomposition, causing it to break down more quickly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hydrogen peroxide is not stored in glass or plastic vessels because it reacts with glass, evaporates quickly, or is highly flammable. Rather, it is stored this way because light and rough surfaces can accelerate the decomposition of H₂O₂, causing it to break down into water and oxygen gas more rapidly.

questions.question_text: Hydrogen gas is used as a rocket fuel because of its:

options.text: High calorific value per unit mass

questions.explanation_correct: Hydrogen gas is used as a rocket fuel because it has a high calorific value (energy content) per unit mass, meaning it releases a large amount of energy when burned. This high energy density makes hydrogen an excellent fuel for powering rockets and spacecraft.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hydrogen gas is not used as a rocket fuel because of its low cost or high density. In fact, hydrogen is a very light gas, with a much lower density than other fuels like kerosene. The green color when burned is also not a relevant property for its use as a rocket fuel. The key reason is its high calorific value per unit mass, which provides the necessary energy to propel rockets and spacecraft.

questions.question_text: Interstitial hydrides are characterized by:

options.text: Being strong reducing agents in solution

questions.explanation_correct: Interstitial hydrides have a non-stoichiometric composition, meaning the ratio of hydrogen to the host metal is not fixed. This allows them to have a range of hydrogen content, unlike ionic hydrides which have a definite stoichiometry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Interstitial hydrides are not gaseous at room temperature, as they are formed by hydrogen atoms occupying the spaces (interstitial sites) between the atoms of transition metals. They also are not strong reducing agents in solution, as their properties depend on the host metal rather than just the hydrogen content.

questions.question_text: When H₂O₂ reacts with acidified KMnO₄, oxygen is evolved. The oxidation state of oxygen changes from:
questions.explanation_correct: The oxidation state of oxygen in hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is -1. When H2O2 reacts with acidified KMnO4, it gets oxidized to O2, where the oxidation state of oxygen is 0. Therefore, the oxidation state of oxygen changes from -1 in H2O2 to 0 in O2, which is the correct answer (option A).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is incorrect because the oxidation state of oxygen in H2O2 is -1, not -2. Option C is incorrect because the oxidation state of oxygen in H2O is -2, not -1 as in H2O2. Option D is incorrect because the oxidation state of oxygen in O2 is 0, not -2 as in H2O.

questions.question_text: The most abundant isotope of hydrogen is:
questions.explanation_correct: The most abundant isotope of hydrogen is protium (¹H), which makes up about 99.985% of natural hydrogen. Protium is the lightest and most common isotope, with a single proton and no neutrons in the nucleus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other isotopes, deuterium (²H) and tritium (³H), are much less abundant in nature. Deuterium makes up about 0.015% of natural hydrogen, and tritium is radioactive with a very low natural abundance. Therefore, the most abundant isotope of hydrogen is protium (¹H), not deuterium or tritium.

questions.question_text: Temporary hardness of water is removed by boiling because:

options.text: Calcium bicarbonate decomposes to insoluble CaCO₃
Water evaporates and leaves salts behind

questions.explanation_correct: Temporary hardness of water is caused by the presence of dissolved calcium and magnesium bicarbonates. When the water is boiled, the bicarbonates decompose to form insoluble calcium carbonate, which precipitates out, removing the temporary hardness.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because calcium sulfate does not precipitate when water is boiled. Option C is incorrect because sodium chloride does not precipitate when water is boiled. Option D is incorrect because while water evaporates when boiled, the salts responsible for temporary hardness (calcium and magnesium bicarbonates) are removed through the decomposition reaction, not by simple evaporation.

questions.question_text: Which of the following elements does NOT form an interstitial hydride?
questions.explanation_correct: Sodium is an alkali metal, and it forms ionic hydrides rather than interstitial hydrides. Interstitial hydrides are formed by transition metals, where the hydrogen atoms fit into the gaps between the metal atoms in the crystal structure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Interstitial hydrides are formed when hydrogen atoms fit into the gaps between the atoms in the crystal structure of certain transition metals, such as palladium, titanium, and vanadium. Sodium, being an alkali metal, forms ionic hydrides instead, where the hydrogen atom has a full negative charge and is bonded to the positive sodium ion.

questions.question_text: The water gas reaction is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B, C + H2O → CO + H2. This reaction is known as the water gas reaction, where carbon (C) reacts with water (H2O) to produce carbon monoxide (CO) and hydrogen (H2). This reaction is used in the industrial production of hydrogen gas.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not the water gas reaction. Option A, 2H2 + O2 → 2H2O, is the reaction for the combustion of hydrogen. Option C, CH4 + H2O → CO + 3H2, is the steam reforming of methane to produce hydrogen. Option D, CO + H2O → CO2 + H2, is the water-gas shift reaction, which is not the same as the water gas reaction.

questions.question_text: Hydrogen can be placed both in Group 1 and Group 17 of the periodic table based on its electronic configuration.
questions.explanation_correct: Hydrogen can be placed in both Group 1 (alkali metals) and Group 17 (halogens) of the periodic table because its electronic configuration of 1s¹ resembles both groups - it has one valence electron like alkali metals, but is also one electron short of a noble gas configuration like halogens.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Some students may think hydrogen cannot be placed in both Group 1 and Group 17 because it does not fit neatly into any one group. However, the unique electronic configuration of hydrogen allows it to exhibit properties of both alkali metals and halogens, making it a 'floating' element that can be classified in either group.

questions.question_text: D₂O has a lower boiling point than H₂O.
questions.explanation_correct: Heavy water (D₂O) has a higher boiling point than ordinary water (H₂O) due to the increased mass of the deuterium atoms. This results in stronger intermolecular forces, leading to a higher boiling point for D₂O compared to H₂O.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect statement is that D₂O has a lower boiling point than H₂O. This is not true because the increased mass of deuterium atoms in heavy water leads to stronger intermolecular forces, which results in a higher boiling point for D₂O compared to ordinary water.

questions.question_text: All ionic hydrides are formed by s-block elements (Groups 1 and 2).
questions.explanation_correct: The statement is true because ionic hydrides are formed by the highly electropositive s-block elements (Groups 1 and 2), which have a strong tendency to donate their lone valence electron to hydrogen, forming ionic compounds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is incorrect because not all ionic hydrides are formed by s-block elements. Some transition metals, such as titanium and zirconium, can also form ionic hydrides by donating their valence electrons to hydrogen. However, the majority of ionic hydrides are indeed formed by the highly reactive s-block elements.

questions.question_text: Hydrogen peroxide can act only as an oxidizing agent and never as a reducing agent.
questions.explanation_correct: Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) can act as both an oxidizing agent and a reducing agent, depending on the reaction conditions. It can oxidize other substances by donating its oxygen atoms, but it can also be reduced itself by accepting electrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is a common misconception that hydrogen peroxide can only act as an oxidizing agent. However, this is not true. Hydrogen peroxide has a dual nature and can also function as a reducing agent in certain chemical reactions. The reason for this is that it has two oxygen atoms, and it can either donate or accept electrons depending on the circumstances.

questions.question_text: The bond dissociation enthalpy of H-H (436 kJ/mol) is higher than that of F-F (159 kJ/mol).
questions.explanation_correct: The bond dissociation enthalpy of H-H (436 kJ/mol) is higher than that of F-F (159 kJ/mol) because the hydrogen-hydrogen bond is a strong covalent bond, while the fluorine-fluorine bond is a relatively weaker single bond. The higher bond strength of H-H makes it more stable and requires more energy to break compared to the F-F bond.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be to assume that the F-F bond is stronger than the H-H bond. This is because fluorine is a highly electronegative element, and the F-F bond requires less energy to break compared to the strong covalent bond in hydrogen. The high bond dissociation enthalpy of H-H is due to the stable electronic configuration of the hydrogen atom, which is just one electron short of the noble gas helium.

questions.question_text: The mass number of deuterium is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The mass number of deuterium is 2 because it has one proton and one neutron in its nucleus, while the common isotope of hydrogen, protium, has only one proton and no neutrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format for the mass number of deuterium is '2'. The mass number represents the total number of protons and neutrons in the nucleus of an atom. Deuterium, also known as heavy hydrogen, has one proton and one neutron in its nucleus, giving it a mass number of 2.

questions.question_text: The oxidation state of oxygen in H₂O₂ is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The oxidation state of oxygen in H2O2 (hydrogen peroxide) is -1. This is because each oxygen atom is bonded to one hydrogen atom, and the oxidation state of hydrogen is +1, so the oxygen atoms have an oxidation state of -1 to balance the overall molecule.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format for this question is '-1'. The incorrect explanation would be that the oxidation state of oxygen in H2O2 is -2. This is because the oxygen atoms are in a -2 oxidation state in most oxygen-containing compounds, such as water (H2O). However, in hydrogen peroxide, the oxygen atoms have a -1 oxidation state since they are bonded to one hydrogen atom each.

questions.question_text: CaH₂ is known as ___ because it reacts with water to produce hydrogen.
questions.explanation_correct: CaH₂ is called a hydrolith because it reacts with water (H₂O) to produce hydrogen gas (H₂). This reaction occurs due to the high reactivity of the calcium hydride compound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'hydrolith'. CaH₂ is considered a hydrolith because it reacts with water to produce hydrogen gas. This happens because the calcium hydride is a highly reactive compound that readily releases hydrogen when in contact with water.

questions.question_text: Water has maximum density at ___ °C.
questions.explanation_correct: Water has maximum density at 4°C because this is the temperature at which the hydrogen bonding in water molecules is most optimized, leading to the highest packing density of water molecules.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format for this question is '4'. While water's density increases as it cools, it reaches a maximum at 4°C, not at 0°C. This is because the hydrogen bonding in water molecules becomes most optimized at 4°C, resulting in the highest packing density of the water molecules.

questions.question_text: The mixture of CO and H₂ obtained by passing steam over hot coke is called ___ gas.
questions.explanation_correct: The mixture of CO and H₂ obtained by passing steam over hot coke is called water gas. This is because the reaction between steam and hot coke produces a mixture of carbon monoxide (CO) and hydrogen (H₂), which is known as water gas.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format for this question is 'water'. The incorrect explanation would be that the mixture of CO and H₂ is called 'syngas' or 'synthesis gas'. This is a common misconception, as syngas is a different mixture of gases produced by the gasification of coal or biomass, not by the reaction of steam and hot coke.

questions.question_text: The dihedral angle in the non-planar structure of H₂O₂ is approximately ___ degrees.
questions.explanation_correct: The dihedral angle in the non-planar structure of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is approximately 111.5 degrees. This angle arises due to the open-book structure of the molecule, where the two oxygen atoms and the two hydrogen atoms are not in the same plane.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format for this question is a number with one decimal place, so the correct answer is 111.5 degrees. The dihedral angle in the non-planar structure of hydrogen peroxide is not 90 degrees or 180 degrees, as those would correspond to a planar structure. The actual angle of 111.5 degrees is due to the steric repulsion between the two oxygen-hydrogen bonds, which forces the molecule to adopt a non-planar, open-book configuration.

questions.question_text: An electron-deficient hydride that contains a three-centre two-electron bond is ___ (formula).
questions.explanation_correct: The formula B₂H₆ is correct because it represents diborane, an electron-deficient hydride that contains a three-centre two-electron bond. This unique bonding structure arises due to the electron-deficient nature of boron, which tries to share electrons with hydrogen to achieve a more stable configuration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct formula for the electron-deficient hydride with a three-centre two-electron bond is B₂H₆, which represents diborane. Some other hydrides like LiH or CH₄ do not have this specific bonding arrangement, so they would not be the correct answer.

questions.question_text: Arrange the isotopes of hydrogen in increasing order of mass: (A) Tritium, (B) Protium, (C) Deuterium
questions.explanation_correct: The isotopes of hydrogen are arranged in increasing order of mass as Protium (¹H), Deuterium (²H), and Tritium (³H). This is because Protium has the lowest mass, Deuterium has a higher mass due to an extra neutron, and Tritium has the highest mass with two extra neutrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be Tritium, Protium, Deuterium. This is wrong because Tritium has the highest mass with three nucleons (one proton and two neutrons), Protium has the lowest mass with just one proton, and Deuterium has an intermediate mass with one proton and one neutron.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following hydrides in increasing order of thermal stability: (A) H₂Te, (B) H₂O, (C) H₂S, (D) H₂Se
questions.explanation_correct: The thermal stability of hydrides increases as the electronegativity difference between the hydrogen and the other element decreases. Hydrogen telluride (H₂Te) has the highest electronegativity difference and is the least stable, while hydrogen oxide (H₂O) has the lowest electronegativity difference and is the most stable, resulting in the correct order: H₂Te, H₂Se, H₂S, H₂O.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct order of increasing thermal stability for the given hydrides is H₂Te, H₂Se, H₂S, H₂O. This is because the stability of hydrides is determined by the electronegativity difference between hydrogen and the other element. As the electronegativity difference decreases, the thermal stability of the hydride increases. Hydrogen telluride (H₂Te) has the highest electronegativity difference, making it the least stable, while hydrogen oxide (H₂O) has the lowest electronegativity difference, making it the most stable.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following methods of removing water hardness by their effectiveness for temporary hardness: (A) Boiling, (B) Adding washing soda, (C) Ion exchange, (D) Clark's method (adding Ca(OH)₂)
questions.explanation_correct: Boiling is the most effective method for removing temporary hardness, as it causes the dissolved calcium and magnesium bicarbonates to precipitate out. Clark's method and adding washing soda are also effective, but less so than boiling. Ion exchange is the least effective of the given methods for removing temporary hardness.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct order of effectiveness for removing temporary hardness is: Boiling, Clark's method, Adding washing soda, Ion exchange. Boiling is the most effective as it causes the dissolved minerals to precipitate out. Clark's method and adding washing soda are also effective, but less so than boiling. Ion exchange is the least effective as it does not actually remove the dissolved minerals, but rather exchanges them for other ions.
